summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ/OIG Senior Special Agent Dennis with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Senior Officer Specialist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York on August 5, 2021. The interview is part of the OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances. The witness discusses his duties, his role in counts on August 9-10, 2019, the discovery of Epstein's body, and systemic issues at the MCC.

events.title: Discovery of Jeffrey Epstein's body
events.description: A body alarm went off at approximately 6:33 a.m. in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Responding officers found Epstein in his cell. Medical staff performed CPR, he was transported to the medical unit and then to a hospital via ambulance.

events.title: Inmate moved to dry cell
events.description: Inmate was observed possibly receiving contraband during a visit in the SHU visitation room at approximately 1:40 p.m. He was placed in a dry cell in R&D (Receiving & Discharge) by 3:15 p.m., but this movement was not properly recorded in the system, leading to inaccurate counts.

events.title: Epstein's alleged first suicide attempt
events.description: The witness references an earlier incident where Epstein allegedly attempted suicide, after which he was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein's cellmate transferred
events.description: Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, was reportedly released or transferred from the MCC on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

keyFacts: The interview reveals significant discrepancies in inmate counts in the Special Housing Unit on the night before and morning of Epstein's death. Count slips showed 73 inmates when there should have been 72, due to an inmate being in R&D dry cell but not properly keyed out of the SHU system.

The witness, a Senior Officer Specialist, was working as Control #1 on August 9 (4pm-midnight) and Internal #2 on August 10 (midnight-8am). He acknowledges potentially 'dropping the ball' by not correcting count paperwork but cannot recall specific conversations or when annotations were made on count slips.

The witness states he believes Epstein committed suicide alone, but suggests systemic problems like lack of staff, failure to keep him on suicide watch, and failure to ensure he had a cellmate contributed to the death.

The document indicates that correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas submitted count slips for the SHU that were inaccurate (showing 73 inmates instead of the correct 72) for multiple counts (4pm, 10pm on Aug 9, and 12am on Aug 10).

The witness mentions hearing rumors that a judge may have contacted the warden regarding Epstein's access to lawyers and paperwork, potentially leading to his premature removal from suicide watch, but clarifies this is just rumor.
